bestBHT.bht: With great fervor, Peter vehemently asserted his loyalty to Jesus, declaring that he would never deny Him. The use of a strong compounded adverb and a double negative intensified the magnitude of his denial, representing the strongest possible affirmation. Peter repeated this declaration vigorously, demonstrating his unwavering conviction in his faithfulness. In solidarity, the other disciples echoed Peter's words, solidifying their steadfast commitment until they reached Gethsemane.

Henry Alford: 31.] spake the more vehemently—the original implies, went on repeating superabundant
Marvin Vincent: I will not deny [ου μη σε απαρνησομαι] . The double negative with the future forms the strongest possible assertion.
Philip Schaff: He spake exceeding vehemently. This might be paraphrased: ‘he went on repeating superabundantly’ The correct reading emphasizes the intensity of the denial.
And in like manner also, etc. These protestations occupied some time, probably continuing until they entered Gethsemane.
Archibald T. Robertson: This strong compounded adverb only in Mark and probably preserves Peter's own statement of the remark.
About the boast of Peter see on Matthew 26:35.
John Gill: He spake the more vehemently, with a louder voice; with more spirit and eagerness; in a more peremptory and self-confident way.
If I should die with thee, I will not deny thee in any wise.
Likewise also said they all; as he said, so said 'all the disciples'.
